content: abuelita gaiter another variation on the bandana gaiter using a triangle that joins to make a tube this simple and versatile construction can be adapted in countless ways materials needed 100g aran weight yarn i hook 5 5mm yarn needle as always i utilize the no-turning-chain-double_crochet video tutorial available on youtube to start each row so there will be no note of a turning chain if you do not know how to do the no-turning-chain-double_crochet or simply prefer not to you may start each row with a ch4 counts as double_crochet ch1 turn your work at the end of each row while working the triangular part of the gaiter after joining to do the collar of the gaiter stop turning and work in the round until finished also this patter begins with a magic_ring magic_ring if you do not like using magic_ring you may do ch3 or ch4 and join into a ring special stitches cluster 3dc worked into indicated chain space begin with magic_ring row 1 work double_crochet ch1 cluster ch2 cluster ch1 double_crochet all into magic_ring row 2 double_crochet in double_crochet ch1 cluster in ch1 from previous row ch1 cluster ch2 cluster in ch2 ch1 cluster in ch1 from previous row ch1 double_crochet in double_crochet row 3 double_crochet in double_crochet ch1 cluster in ch1 from previous row 2 times ch1 cluster ch2 cluster in ch2 ch1 cluster in ch1 from previous row 2 times ch1 double_crochet in double_crochet repeat row 3 adding 1 cluster per side if you ve ever made a traditional granny square this will come very easily until the top edge of the gaiter just reaches around the largest part of your head join the first and last double_crochet of your last row with slip_stitch look below for a crudely-drawn chart… collar work double_crochet sts evenly across the top edge of the triangle join to first double_crochet with a slip_stitch i recommend trying it on at this point to make sure it is not too tight to easily slide over your head to avoid frogging later repeat as needed until the collar is the height you want it i gave mine extra length so it could be folded over weave in ends block if desired this pattern uses a standard half-granny square to create the triangle part of this gaiter this construction can be adapted for any right-angled triangle pattern that you like the best if you feel confident enough with your skills you can even halve your favorite square pattern on the diagonal to turn it into a right-angled triangle to adapt it for this pattern have fun
